repository.name: xo
repository.description: ❤️ JavaScript/TypeScript linter (ESLint wrapper) with great defaults

body:
Hi, thanks for the report. However, this is working as intended -- to fix the issue you should write the code like this:

```js
const { [someIndex]: value } = array.
```

Thanks for the quick answer!
As this is a bit of convoluted way to use destructuring maybe it would be a good idea to add it to the example in the "correct" section of the rule documentation. Maybe adding to the existing example something like that:

Examples of correct code when `enforceForRenamedProperties` is enabled:
```js
/* eslint prefer-destructuring: ["error", {array: true}, {enforceForRenamedProperties: true}] */

[bar] = array;

const { [someIndex]: value } = array
```
Improving the documentation sounds like a good idea to me. Would you be willing to make a PR?
Yeah sure! Can you assign the issue to me?

rename.from: prefer-destructuring doesn't allow to use variable for array indexes with option enforceForRenamedProperties
rename.to: Clarify doc and examples for enforceForRenamedProperties option of prefer-destructuring rule

issue.title: Docs: Add prefer-destructuring examples (fixes #9970)

labels.name: archived due to age
labels.description: This issue has been archived; please open a new issue for any further discussion

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

[ ] Add something to the core
[ ] Other, please explain:

**What changes did you make? (Give an overview)**

Add examples for the `prefer-destructuring` rules when `enforceForRenamedProperties` is enabled.

**Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?**

Nothing in particular.

body: This issue should have been closed along wit #9989. Can it be done manually?
@santanaG We could close this manually, but should we? I'm not clear on if there is still an issue here (i.e., if there is something to be resolved in a different way than what #9989 tried to do).
@platinumazure  *facepalm* Apologies, I just realized that it actually closed and the changes were not accepted!

I was confused by this rule as well. I had a read through the discussion in #9989 and had a look at the source code.

It seems to me that the confusion mostly comes from the fact that the rule and the documentation use the terms `"array"` and `"object"`, while what the code is actually checking is merely whether the property being accessed is a number or not (in the code: `function isArrayIndexAccess(node) {return Number.isInteger(node.property.value);}`). Hence the following counter-intuitive situations:

- Accessing an array element through a computed index will fall under the category `"object"`.
- Accessing an object property whose key is an integer will fall under the category `"array"`. 

I'm happy to submit a PR to propose 2 sentences that could add some clarification to the documentation.

Ultimately it seems impossible to fully realize the intent of this rule through mere static code analysis...
